description: From Latin indubitatus, past participle of indubitare; prefix in- (“in”) + dubitare (“to doubt”).

adjectives.description: indubitate (comparative more indubitate, superlative most indubitate)

entries.meaning: Not questioned or doubtful; evident; certain.
examples: On the other side, if he stood upon his own title of the house of Lancaster, inherent in his person, he knew it was a title condemned by parliament, and generally prejudged in the common opinion of the realm, and that it tended directly to the disinherison of the line of York, held then the indubitate heirs of the crown.

verbs.description: indubitate (third-person singular simple present indubitates, present participle indubitating, simple past and past participle indubitated)

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To bring into doubt; to cause to be doubted.
